ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: A further understanding of Japanese. This includes new grammar, vocabulary, daily expressions, and useful cultural information.
I improved my Japanese by leaps and bounds, and I got a firm grasp on a variety of grammar structures, vocabulary, and writing techniques.
I really saw my Japanese improve this semester - I became more comfortable with all linguistic faculties, from listening, to speaking, to reading.
My Japanese grammar, kanji, vocabulary, and pitch accent improved a lot.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
The course is well structured, with each grammar lesson leading into the next. 

This year we were the "guinea pigs" for a new workbook being tested out. For the most part this was a good thing, as we did not have to pay for a workbook (the test version was free), but there were occasional hiccups/errors in them.
This course is very engaging and can teach you a lot in a very short amount of time. However, it can often feel as if you are drinking from a firehose.

Strengths: very engaging and well-structured for rapid progress
Weaknesses: very, very high workload!
The professor is very engaging and the class is structured to give a lot of practice with peers.

Strengths: very engaging class, well-organized
Weaknesses: none (just don't take the class half-heartedly, it's a lot of work)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! For anyone looking to continue studying Japanese, I would highly recommend this course. While (like any language course) there is no small amount of homework, it is well put together and leads to observable improvements in Japanese ability.

This course is the most work I've ever had at Yale, and I've taken two classes that people call the "highest workload class." It seems you can still get by fine without putting in as much work as me, but it can be stressful if you're trying to learn the language and you have other commitments.
Yes I would! It is a significant amount of work, but the amount you learn in ratio to the length of a semester is unparalleled.
Yes - Japanese is such an exciting language, and the instructors at Yale make the course so enjoyable!
Yes, the class is very good for improving Japanese language skill and introducing you to Japanese culture.
If you are intent on learning Japanese
